name: Water
tagline: Audubon and its partners engage the public on water-management and water-quality issues; restore habitats along rivers, wetlands, and deltas; and explore market based solutions that contribute to the achievement of our water goals.

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: Water is the lifeline for the places that matter to birds. Wetlands, lakes, rivers, estuaries, and deltas are vital habitats for birds across the Western Hemisphere and around the world.  Without water, or with too little or too much water at the wrong time, the functionality of these natural systems is compromised and the result is a lack of food and quality habitat that birds and other wildlife depend on for their survival. Audubon's Water Strategy aims to advance sustainable water management to protect the most important habitats for birds across the hemisphere.

list: 20 percent increase in protected/managed habitat acres that are important wintering, breeding stopover sites for birds in the three key landscapes
1 million acres of land managed, restored and protected in critical watersheds

International, federal and state policy actions that ensure adequate flows to critical ecosystems, including the Colorado River Delta, the Salton Sea, the Mississippi River and Delta, and the Greater Everglades
20 percent increase in Federal and State funding/incentives to enhance water management and restoration action
200,000 people engaged in advocacy on water conservation measures

25,000 people participating in the new Water for Birds Program – a native habitat/xeriscaping program designed to inform and engage individuals and community members in actions that benefit ecosystems – thus reducing water consumption by 300 million gallons
75 chapters and 10 Audubon Sanctuaries and Centers engaged in advocacy, education and on the ground actions
